_prev_prog_2.MD_OtherType: Manual observations as reequired by TCEQ permit (visual and smell check of area on periodic basis).
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Ammonia transfer pump and transfer hoses.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY OF B & E GRAIN, INC.  VENUS, TX

1.  THE FACILITY POLICY
     The owners, management, and employees of B & E Grain, Inc. (the facility) are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release would occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local police and fire departmets (and/or other authorities), to mitigate any releases and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

2.  FACILITY INFORMATION
     The primary activity at the facility is the storage and distribution of anhydrous ammonia for direct application as a crop production nutrient.
     The maximum quanity stored would be 49,350 pounds located in a 12,000 gallon storage tank. The maximum amount transfered at any one time would be the unloading of an 9,200 gallon truck trailer.

3.  WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO
     a.  The worst-case release scenario would be the release of the total contents of the 12,000 gallon storage tank released over 10 minutes.  The maximum quantity released would be 49,350 pounds which represents the volume of the storage tank at 80 percent capacity as limited by design standards.  The distance to the endpoint is 2.6 miles as calculated using RMP Comp.

     b.  The alternative release scenario based on the most likey potential incident is a release from a valve left open by an unauthorized person (during a theft of ammonia for drug production).  A total of 150 pounds of ammonia could be released from a partially frozen cut off valve over a time period of 30 minutes.  This time period would be sufficient for the ammonia release to develop into a nuisance smell and be noticed and reported.  The distance to the toxic endpoint is 0.1 miles as calculated using RMP Comp.

4.  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
     The facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhyydrous Ammonia, K-61.1, published by T

he American National Standards Institute, Inc., and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia".

5.  FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
     There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that:
     -  have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility: nor

     -  to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property
        damage, or environmental damage.

    The only emissions from the plant were  in the form of a nuisance smell from a valve being left partially open following a thieft  of ammonia from one of the nurse tanks that was left behind by a farmer because of incliement weather.

6.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
     The faciliy has:
     a.  a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29CFR 1910.38

     b.  a written emergency response program, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.120,
          including pre-emergency planning and employee training.

     c.  provided state and local authorities the emergency plannin and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).

7.  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
     All of the portable ammonia trailers are stored empty behind a secure fence.  Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
